title: Cradle 2 Cradle for the 3rd Industrial Revolution
segmentation: Thank you very much dear ministers.
Dear Ambassador dear guest, I'm very happy to be here today invited into Slovenia to present to you a few cases of practical experiences in implementing cradle to cradle.
I did started this in 1993 in Switzerland.
With the textile, the ones who wrote who read the book, it's about the Climate X story.
And since then really was involved all that time, so it's 17 years ago, 17 years ago.
So now it should be ready to be grown up to go out there and really promote this.
Six years ago I left that company and I joined the EPA organization in Hamburg from Michael Braungart.
And this is an environmental scientific Institute, and it was founded by Michael Brown, Guard, one of the two founders of Cradle to Cradle in 1987.
So cradle Cradle was founded by William McDonald, an architect in America, and Michael Braungart, a chemist.
Michael Brown Guard, was former, the head of the chemical division of Greenpeace.
And he realized in 1987.
It is the wrong pass of Greenpeace of always accusing industry of doing the things bad.
And he said we have to support industry.
We have to help industry and he found it EPA.
At EPA is from the Americell American Environmental Protection Agency and EPA means Environmental Protection encouragement agency.
First, he named it enforcement agency.
Can we see that Mr Sound?
Maybe that's irritating.
And we are now a team of about 40 scientists.
So biologists, chemists, physicists, environmental engineers and really trying to implement cradle to cradle strategies, helping the industry and support the industry.
When I joined, EPA's CEO in Hamburg, I tried to really make this a business.
In the good sense, what does what does that mean, making it explainable to business?
What these scientists are doing?
So presenting giving a face of science to industry?
What does that mean?
And we were very, very successful.
And four years ago suddenly the Dutch people came.
And wanted to become a cradle to cradle country.
And why did this happen?
It happened because they saw the film from Al Gore Unconvenient truth.
And suddenly their country was not on the map anymore.
So I don't want to be impolite, but somehow they got into a midlife crisis.
What options do we have?
And.
We had a really a coincidence and we're really lucky that a Dutch journalist.
Made a movie about cradle to cradle and this called waste equals food.
And this movie was presented to the Dutch people and the television several times in the summer of 2006.
And so they became aware that is a solution.
But we as an organization, what are you doing if suddenly a country is going that Rd?
We were a baby, a bunch of people, maybe about 20 people, 20 scientists.
What can you do?
Well, we reflected and said the only thing we can do is trying to give a frame.
To that area where everyone understands what they would do, whatever they have to do, and the other thing is we have to try to build some good examples.
Good examples which show the difference.
That can be done and this is what we have been doing and I became CEO of VPI Netherland and end of last year.
We were really successful.
A lot of products are now in the market in the Netherlands.
Few of those are displayed over there.
I decided to go back to my roots.
Because in the area where I come from, I come from Switzerland.
If you look at the area of Stuttgart, Munich, Vienna.
Milano and Leo this rectangular.
The Alpine regions.
Is the industrial heart of Europe.
And we have not done many much projects in that area because of the Dutch people, because the Dutch people forced us to give all our energy into the Netherlands.
So I went back and found it eppi Switzerland meaning of this year.
And you see all our participants now in these different areas.
So Slovenia is still open and we're really trying to see.
What we can do to really develop some projects and help industry in doing this?
What are we doing?
We are assessing materials we're looking into material streams.
Cradle Cradle is about really getting a focus on material streams, assessing materials if they are safe for biological or technical cycles.
We do offer a lot of research to find.
Other innovations where we can replace substances which are not OK.
But at the end we have to define.
Some new business service concepts because as well the business will change.
Because we're sinking in cycles, we want to get these goods somehow back.
We want to keep the quality of the raw materials at the same level.
We don't talk about recycling that much because that's most of the time downcycling so we want to keep the raw materials in multiple lifecycles, but maintain the quality.
So as a business you really have to see that your relationship to your suppliers will be a different one in the future because you want to know what's in the material.
And the other thing is as well as the customers you have to start another relationship because you want to know to whom?
Who is he selling these products to?
I do have to establish a relationship with the consumer.
And how difficult that is for businesses?
I think we all.
Well.
There's always a controversy between sustainability and cradle to cradle.
It's a different way of thinking, and we could say cradle to cradle is beyond sustainability.
This is what I like the most.
And if you look at the perspective.
Sustainability is cradle to grave and cradle cradle is really cradle to cradle in a cycle.
The orientation is.
From sustainability problems to reduce, avoid minimize.
OK, that's the efficiency approach.
And Cradle cradle is more Environmental Quality goals to reach, so it's trying to reach a different level of quality.
And the methodology is from sustainability.
Linear because we have all been educated to sink in a linear way.
And trailer trailers sinking in a circle away.
And this circular means as well back and forecasting in a cycle.
That's very important in product design because productivity is crucial.
And the indicators are quantitative and incredible.

All industries.
